subject: BoJ Summary of Opinions state there has been no further increase in the possibility that the momentum toward achieving the price  stability  target  will  be  lost, adds it is appropriate to maintain the current guidelines for market operations
content:
Says: 

  • Japan's economy has been on a moderate expanding trend, although exports, production, and business sentiment have shown some weakness, mainly affected by the slowdown in overseas economies and natural disasters.
  • Probability the global economy will follow its recovery trend through the middle of this year seems to be increasing.
  • Although risks concerning overseas economies remain significant, signs of recovery have started to be observed in part.
  • CPI is likely to increase gradually toward 2 percent, mainly on the back of the output gap remaining positive and medium-to long-term inflation expectations rising,
  • May need to conduct review of policy framework given heightening debate in Europe and US over 'Japanification'.
  • Post-sales tax hike recovery in consumption has been weak.

Full release: http://www.boj.or.jp/en/mopo/mpmsche_minu/opinion_2020/opi200121.pdf
analysis_details: As a reminder, the BoJ kept all policy settings unchanged at the meeting with NIRP kept at -0.1% and 10yr JGB yield target at around 0% as widely expected which resulted to a muted reaction across asset classes. BoJ also maintained forward guidance that rates will remain at current or lower levels for as long as needed to guard against risk momentum for hitting price target may be lost, but suggested that downside risks regarding overseas economies eased somewhat which was likely due to recent US-China Phase 1 signing. Furthermore, the central bank's views on inflation remain subdued and far from the 2% target, although it upgraded growth forecasts in the Outlook Report which was not much of a surprise given the surge in growth for Q3 and after the Japan announced a JPY 13.2tln economic package last month.

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

World Health Organisation stated that they have not seen any onward human-to-human spread of coronavirus by travellers returning from China, aside from one case in Vietnam which is good news. However, there were reports that a man in Germany was infected with the coronavirus from a woman who travelled to Wuhan which is being portrayed as person-to-person transmission, although it was unclear if this is explicitly the case. (Newswires/Focus)

People's Daily reported the coronavirus outbreak may reach its peak in one week or around 10 days and then there will be no large-scale increases, according to renowned Chinese respiratory expert Zhong Nanshan. (People’s Daily)

Hong Kong researchers have developed the coronavirus vaccine although it would take months to test it on animals and at least another year to conduct clinical trials, according to reports in SCMP citing a disease expert. In related news, Global Times noted that China is likely to have a public use vaccine for the Coronavirus within 3-months citing a Chinese Academy of Engineering academic. (SCMP/Global Times)

US NIH official said they hope to advance coronavirus vaccine into Phase 1 trials within three months, while there were separate comments from the US Health Secretary that the use of face masks in the US to counter coronavirus is not necessary as the risks to individuals are currently very low. (Newswires)

White House is mulling China travel restrictions according to CNBC citing sources. (CNBC)

A fourth case of coronavirus has been confirmed in France and there were separate reports of a suspected coronavirus case in Birmingham, UK in which a person felt ill after returning from Wuhan. (Figaro/Daily Mail)

PBoC stated that the Central Bank will offer abundant liquidity after the Lunar New Year Holiday through Open Market Operations. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK Government granted permission for Huawei to construct non-core sections of the UK telecom network although it has been designated a high-risk vendor and will have a market share cap of 35%, while it will be excluded from sensitive geographic locations. (Newswires)

US Republican Senator Graham said the UK's decision for Huawei could "greatly complicate" a free trade agreement between the two sides, while a report also noted that US Politicians are said to be ‘furious’ at the UK’s decision on Huawei with some suggesting they could take a harder line in post-Brexit trade negotiations as a result. (Newswires/LBC)

EU will not ban Huawei from their telecommunications network but will be imposing strict 5G rules, according to AFP citing an Official. (AFP)

 

COMMODITIES

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks (w/e 24th Jan) -4.3mln (exp. +0.5mln, prev. +1.6mln). (Newswires)

OPEC are reportedly discussing extending oil output cuts until at least June and could deepen output cuts if prices & demand falls on spread of the coronavirus, according to OPEC sources. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US and Israel proposed two-state solution for Israel and Palestine with the Palestine capital in Jerusalem. Israel agreed to negotiate on the basis of a detailed proposed map, while agreement for statehood for Palestinians is contingent on security arrangements to protect Israelis, as well as Palestines respect for human rights, freedom of press and transparent judiciary. Furthermore, US President Trump commented that this is the first time Israel has authorized the release of a proposed and consensual map for an Israeli-Palestinian peace plan, although the President of the State of Palestine Abbas stated the deal plot will not pass and Jerusalem is not for sale, while a Hamas official also described the peace plan as 'aggressive' and as 'nonsense'. (Newswires) 

 

US

US President Trump said the Fed should get smart & lower the rate to make our interest competitive with other countries, while he added we would then focus on paying off & refinancing debt and suggested there is almost no inflation. (Newswires)

US CBO sees FY20 budget deficit of USD 1.015trln and USD 1trln in FY21, while it expects US economic growth of 2.2% in 2020, 1.8% in 2021 and the US economy to grow at an average rate of 1.7% over the next decade. (Newswires)

  • US Durable Goods (Dec) 2.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. -2.1%, Rev. -3.1%). (Newswires) 
  • US Consumer Confidence (Jan) 131.6 vs. Exp. 128.0 (Prev. 126.5, Rev. 128.2)
  • US Richmond Fed Composite Index (Jan) 20 (Prev. -5.0)

Apple (AAPL) Q1 '20 earnings (USD): EPS 4.99 (Exp. 4.55); Revenue 91.82 (exp. 88.50bln), iPhone: 55.96bln (exp. 51.51bln), iPads: 5.98bln (exp. 6.70bln), Mac: 7.16bln (exp. 7.15bln), Services: 12.72bln (exp. 13.07bln). (Newswires) 

 

MARKET RECAP

The tone of trading was more constructive on Tuesday, with equities firming and bonds selling off; gold also saw downside, while the crude complex is also a touch firmer. There have been some suggestions that a vaccine for the Coronavirus is in the pipeline, possibly ready within a three-month window. Additionally, some desks noted that business television spent a lot of the day talking about 'when to buy the dip'. There was also support on the data front, after a solid consumer confidence report, and sharp rises in the Richmond Fed's manufacturing gauge; the headline durable goods data was good, but internals were soft. In terms of earnings, 3M (MMM) underperformed in the DJ following a rather dismal report which missed on EPS and revenue, whilst also providing disappointing guidance. MMM also announced structural changes where it will cut up to 1500 jobs. United Technologies (UTX) traded higher following top and bottom line beats. Pfizer (PFE) were hit after EPS missed estimates and FY20 EPS forecasts were slightly light than the analyst mid-point expectations. Lockheed Martin (LMT) traded marginally higher following an EPS beat, although revenue missed expectations. Guidance however was firmer than expectations on revenue, but short on EPS. Mylan (MYL) rose after Pfizer (PFE) CEO announced the combination of MYL and Upjohn to create a global Pharmaceutical company will close this year. Apple (AAPL) saw gains of ~3% ahead of its figures tonight following reports it asked suppliers to ready for an increase in iPhone production by 10% in H1, however suppliers have stated it may face difficulties with this due to the Coronavirus spreading across China, according to Nikkei. SPX +1% AT 3276; DOW +0.65% AT 28722; NDX +1.55% AT 9091.

Yields were higher across the curve by between 2.5-4.5bps, at settlement, with the shape of the curve marginally steeper. It helped the 2s5s and 3m/10-year spreads to both go positive, having briefly inverting in the last 24hrs. A more constructive risk tone was cited. The US Treasury sold 7-year notes, tailing 0.4bps (the 2s, 5s, and 7s auctions have all tailed this week), though cover was in line with recent averages. The internals were more or less in line with recent averages; Directs took 17.2% against recent average of 15.7%; indirects took 58.1% against an average of 61.5%, while dealers were left with 24.7% against recent average of 22.7%. US T-note futures settled 9 ticks lower at 130-19+.

subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 28th January 2020: Risk assets see some reprieve following prior days sell off
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Dollar flat, Crude up.
  • REAR VIEW: US Durables beat, core figures miss. Strong consumer confidence and Richmond Fed; Reports of vaccines for coronavirus ease some tensions, although cases continue to rise. UK gives Huawei the go ahead on its non-core assets.
  • COMING UP: Data & Events: Fed Rate Decision; US Pending Home Sales and Advanced Goods Trade Balance; Australian CPI; New Zealand Trade Balance.

* MARKETS WRAP: The tone of trading was more constructive on Tuesday, with equities firming and bonds selling off; gold also saw downside, while the crude complex is also a touch firmer. There have been some suggestions that a vaccine for the Coronavirus is in the pipeline, possibly ready within a three-month window. Additionally, some desks noted that business television spent a lot of the day talking about 'when to buy the dip'. There was also support on the data front, after a solid consumer confidence report, and sharp rises in the Richmond Fed's manufacturing gauge; the headline durable goods data was good, but internals were soft. The tone of earnings was mixed; MMM, PFE weren't great, although LMT and HCA were good. After market, tech giant AAPL, EBAY, AMD, SBUX are on the slate. Casting our attention slightly ahead, MSFT and FOMC are the highlights for Wednesday.

* CORONAVIRUS: A lot more new cases have been reported on Tuesday, however, the panic seems to have eased, judging by the performance of equities (up) and bonds today (down). Perhaps market jitters have been soothed by reports in Chinese press that Hong Kong researchers have already developed a vaccine for the coronavirus, but need time to test it, according to the SCMP. Meanwhile, the Global Times, also citing academics, reported that China was likely to have a vaccine for public use within three months, which will include a month and a half of development and a month and half of testing.

* DURABLE GOODS (DEC): It was a mixed durable goods report, with the headline at 2.4% M/M, above the consensus 0.4%. However, the breakdown was less encouraging, and there were downward revisions to many of the metrics. Pantheon Macroeconomics said the headline was driven by the hit to civilian aircraft orders (Boeing BA received orders for just three aircraft in December, vs an average of 234 over the previous five Decembers) which was offset by a bigger rebound in orders for defense aircraft orders than we expected, while transportation orders ex-aircraft and autos jumped unexpectedly by 14.2%. Pantheon says that no details of the latter are provided in the report, but the jump looks like noise, and will likely reverse. The consultancy also notes that the strong rise in the headline masks the weaker details, noting that orders for non-defense capital goods down 0.9%, the worst performance since April. "The monthly numbers are noisy, though, and the trend is drifting down slowly, much less bad than the rollover implied by business surveys," Pantheon says, "this story seems unlikely to change much in the near future."

* CONSUMER CONFIDENCE (JAN): Consumer Confidence jumped in January to 131.6 against an expected 128.0, while the previous reading was revised up to 128.2 from 126.5. The 1-year consumer inflation expectations rose one-tenth to 4.5%, while the differential between jobs 'plentiful' and jobs 'hard to get' was 37.4 in Jan (prev. 33.9 in December from 31.6 in November), auguring well for the upcoming jobs report. ING said the data was excellent, and now close to all-time highs. "This is understandable given record low unemployment, record high home and equity prices and the lowest national gasoline prices since last March, though adds that weak wage growth and global health worries may limit the transmission to spending.

* UK HUAWEI DECISION: UK Government have given permission for Huawei to construct non-core sections of the UK telecom network, has been designated a high-risk vendor; have a market share cap of 35% and excluded from sensitive geographic locations. The decision by the UK to let Huawei take part in the UK’s 5G infrastructure comes in line with UK press reports. With the Chinese telecom giant now allowed to build parts of the 'non-critical' infrastructure for the network, focus shifts towards any potential strains on UK-US relations. The decision will likely be met with disappointment by the Trump administration with this sentiment likely to be echoed by US Secretary of State Pompeo, while will be visiting London tomorrow. UBS highlights that Republicans in Congress believe that the decision means that co-operation on security between the two nations needs to be re-calibrated in order to protect US interests. Those taking an even more hawkish view could be inclined to cast doubts over the viability of a US-UK free trade deal. Note, PM Johnson will travel to Washington next week for the commencement of trade talks, however, UBS suggests that President Trump could be more inclined to exert pressure on contentious bilateral issues such as Huawei, Iran or digital taxation rather than discussion options for a trade deal. Ahead of that visit, there have already been reports that US Politicians are 'furious' at the UK's decision on Huawei with some suggesting they 'could take a harder line in post-Brexit trade negotiations as a result.'

* WTI (H0) SETTLED USD /BBL AT USD /BBL; BRENT (H0) SETTLED USD AT USD /BBL: Prices found some upward relief on Tuesday following a slew of daily losses in the oil benchmarks, of late. Coronavirus is still an issue, however, perceptions of downside seem to have at least temporarily abated on Tuesday. There was an initial bout of strength in the European session after OPEC sources reported that the group is reportedly discussing extending its oil output cuts until at least June and could deepen the cuts if prices and demand falls on the spread of the coronavirus – Citigroup adds that it believes an extension was necessary to maintain balance in the physical market even without the expected weakening in demand, but now sees potential for stronger/earlier commitments ahead of the March 5-6 summit in Vienna. The crude complex found its second wind on the US cash equity open, alongside the major bourses, as participants further pared back some of Monday’s risk off tone. As attention wanes somewhat from the coronavirus, this week’s US energy inventories come into view; current expectations (bbls): crude +0.5mln, gasoline +1.3mln, distillates -1.1mln and Genscape forecast Cushing at -0.87mln. NOTE: Brent options for March expire at today’s settlement.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES SETTLE 9 TICKS LOWER AT 130-19+. Yields were higher across the curve by between 2.5-4.5bps, at settlement, with the shape of the curve marginally steeper. It helped the 2s5s and 3m/10-year spreads to both go positive, having briefly inverting in the last 24hrs. A more constructive risk tone was cited. The US Treasury sold 7-year notes, tailing 0.4bps (the 2s, 5s, and 7s auctions have all tailed this week), though cover was in line with recent averages. The internals were more or less in line with recent averages; Directs took 17.2% against recent average of 15.7%; indirects indirects took 58.1% against an average of 61.5%, while dealers were left with 24.7% against recent average of 22.7%.

* ECB: ECB's de Cos said it is a priority for countries with high debt and structural deficit to get their public finances in order, but countries with fiscal room could contribute with fiscal stimulus to support their economies. De Cos adder that there is an urgent need to find a solution to the WTO's current impasse.

* FOMC PREVIEW: Rates are seen unchanged at 1.50-1.75%. Officials appear comfortable with the current stance, though markets still see a rate cut in 2020. A 'technical' IOER hike is possible. No SRF announcement expected, details sought. No SEP update until March. The narrative may be more pertinent for longer-term themes like balance sheet policy and the framework review. Meanwhile, perceptions about the Fed's commitment to accommodation may be a catalyst for any price moves. To download the report, please click here.

* STOCK CLOSES: SPX +1% AT 3276; DOW +0.65% AT 28722; NDX +1.55% AT 9091.

* SECTORS: Cons Disc +1%, Cons Staples +0.01, Energy +0.4%, Financials +1.1%, Health +0.5%, Industrials +0.6%, Materials +1%, Technology +1.9%, Communications +1.2%, Utilities +0.4%.

* CORONAVIRUS STOCKS: Macau exposed casino names (LVS, WYNN, MLCO) are under watch as the confirmed cases rise to seven from five, yesterday. Elsewhere, integrated resort operators are reportedly rolling out lengthy lists of closures to help prevent the spreading of the virus, according to Inside Asia Gaming. Elsewhere, pharmaceutical names, AbbVie (ABBV), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) and Gilead (GILD) are among companies that have begun shipping HIV approved drugs to test against the Coronavirus, according to WSJ. During trade, it was also announced that JNJ has begun developing a coronavirus vaccine. Of note for airlines, GS analysts highlight United Airlines (UAL) has highest exposure to China and Hawaiian Holding (HA) has most exposure to total Pacific and East Asia. However, given the heavy sell-off yesterday some names have pared back some of the losses, with AAL trading ~1% higher following a 5% fall yesterday. Also of note, UAL suspended some flights between hub cities and Beijing, Hong Kong and Shanghai due to a poor demand for China travel.

* EARNINGS: 3M (MMM) underperformed in the DJ following a rather dismal report which missed on EPS and revenue, whilst also providing disappointing guidance. MMM also announced structural changes where it will cut up to 1500 jobs. United Technologies (UTX) traded higher following top and bottom line beats. Pfizer (PFE) were hit after EPS missed estimates and FY20 EPS forecasts were slightly light than the analyst mid-point expectations. Lockheed Martin (LMT) traded marginally higher following an EPS beat, although revenue missed expectations. Guidance however was firmer than expectations on revenue, but short on EPS. The revenue breakdown for LMT was strong, which beat expectations across Aeronautics, Missiles and Fire control, Rotary and Mission Systems, and Space. Juniper (JNPR) were hit on slightly weak Q1 20 guidance. McCormick (MKC) traded in the red following poor FY20 guidance. Over in Europe, tech giant SAP (SAP GY) disappointed following a slight miss in revenue and operating profit, however EPS was strong, and it lifted guidance. LVMH (MC FP, LVMUY) ADR’s saw choppy price action following the release which seemed positive at first, however, its revenue organic growth rose less than expected.

* STOCK-SPECIFICS: Mylan (MYL) rose after Pfizer (PFE) CEO announced the combination of MYL and Upjohn to create a global Pharmaceutical company will close this year. Apple (AAPL) saw gains of ~3% ahead of its figures tonight following reports it asked suppliers to ready for an increase in iPhone production by 10% in H1, however suppliers have stated it may face difficulties with this due to the Coronavirus spreading across China, according to Nikkei.

* FX WRAP: USD traded slightly firmer yet again amid firm stateside data, DXY crossed 98 to the upside, a figure it is just under heading into APAC trade. CNH found some support as reports crept in regarding potential vaccines for the coronavirus. EURUSD bounced of the 1.10 figure after falling in the morning before ending the session flat. GBPUSD similarly after a foray sub-1.30, sterling has recovered the figure ahead of Thursday’s BOE, where markets are still expecting the rate decision to be a coin toss. JPY and XAU pared back some of the prior day gains following the prior day safe haven bid, with USDJPY back above 109; real rates were a contributing factor to the XAU downside. Antipodes have pared losses to trade just shy of flat ahead of the close, with the AUD remaining under 0.68 and NZD beneath 0.66. EMFX was generally firmer against the buck, with TRY the relative underperformer as oil prices pick up from the prior days decline, which in turn saw RUB strength, despite weak retail and wage data. MXN firmer amid a wider trade surplus.

content:
Q1 Expectations (USD)

  • EPS: 4.55
  • Revenue: 88.50bln

Analyst Ratings: 11 Strong Buys, 14 Buys, 12 Holds, 5 Sells, 0 Strong Sells

Heading into its earnings (excluding some recent market volatility) the SPX behemoth has had a strong run in the prior year - outperforming the index by approximately threefold in the past three months - taking its market cap past and further away from the USD 1trln milestone; Deutsche Bank’s Ong (“Hold” rating, USD 290 PT) says the rally “bodes poorly” for investors considering what to do with their holdings. Analysts are drawing attention to its iPhone 11, in addition to its popular Air Pods, as expected growth drivers, in addition to indication on the strength of its Apple TV+ service post-launch. Additionally, participants will be eager to gauge the Co’s outlook/progress on 5G rollout and maybe any potential impact from the coronavirus - China is a key growth market for Apple.

Credit Suisse’s Cabral (“Neutral” rating/ USD 275 PT) believes investor focus is shifting increasingly to the 5G iPhone in the latter half of the year, which should help it reignite iPhone revenue growth, albeit against much easier Y/Y comps. Elsewhere, RBC Capital’s Muller (“Outperform” rating, USD 330 PT) cites his data checks suggesting estimates for Q1 are reasonable, whilst highlighting a slight beat on consensus figures could be seen due to strength in iPhone and wearables sales. Meanwhile, Atlantic Equities’ Cordwell (“Underweight”, USD 275) believes upside potential from the 5G expansion has been “more than fully priced in” and believes services and wearables lack upside momentum and iPhone ASP pressure could cause revenue disappointment.

analysis_details: Prices found some upward relief on Tuesday following a slew of daily losses in the oil benchmarks, of late. Coronavirus is still an issue, however, perceptions of downside seem to have at least temporarily abated on Tuesday. There was an initial bout of strength in the European session after OPEC sources reported that the group is reportedly discussing extending its oil output cuts until at least June and could deepen the cuts if prices and demand falls on the spread of the coronavirus – Citigroup adds that it believes an extension was necessary to maintain balance in the physical market even without the expected weakening in demand, but now sees potential for stronger/earlier commitments ahead of the March 5-6 summit in Vienna. The crude complex found its second wind on the US cash equity open, alongside the major bourses, as participants further pared back some of Monday’s risk off tone. As attention wanes somewhat from the coronavirus, this week’s US energy inventories come into view; current expectations (bbls): crude +0.5mln, gasoline +1.3mln, distillates -1.1mln and Genscape forecast Cushing at -0.87mln. THIS WEEK'S SUPPLY: The US Treasury will this week auction a new 2-year note (USD 40bln, Monday), a new 5-year note (USD 41bln, Monday) and a new 7-year note (USD 32bln, Tuesday). It will also auction a new 2-year FRN (USD 20bln, Tuesday). UBS says this week will cashflows of around USD 93bln (ex SOMA holdings, including around USD 84bln of redemptions, and around USD 9bln of coupons), implying net cashflows are around flat.

7-YEAR PREVIEW: The current 7-year is trading fair on asset swap against older 7s, SocGen observes, though the bank feels it trades rich on the fly against 5s and 10s. The WI yield is trading above recent stop-out rates, suggesting it trades rich on an outright basis vs previous cycles. With that said, SocGen notes that the last four 7s auctions have been digested well, seeing strong foreign participation, and SocGen thinks that this strong demand may help to offset some of the richness within the sector. The bank has a neutral bias heading into the auction, but notes demand might be affected by Wednesday's FOMC meeting.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Sterling slides, Dollar strides and Euro (just) survives
content:
GBP/EUR

The Pound has been under pressure from the outset and especially once 1.3050 in Cable and 0.8450 in Eur/Gbp were breached amidst reports of RHS demand for the cross ahead of month end. However, Sterling subsequently lost grip of the 1.3000 handle vs the Dollar without any further Eur/Gbp upside and when Eur/Usd dipped briefly below 1.1000, as UK PM Johnson confirmed restricted 5G access to Huawei and the probability of a BoE rate cut on Thursday remains just above 50%.

USD 

In stark contrast, Greenback strength has been pretty persistent and widespread on the back of China’s escalating coronavirus and increased efforts to contain the outbreak. Indeed, the DXY is forming a firmer base above the 98.000 handle and was not unduly rattled by typically mixed US durable goods or revisions before better than expected consumer confidence ahead of the Fed on Wednesday – full preview of the first FOMC policy meeting of 2020 available on our Research Suite.

CHF/JPY/NZD/AUD

All underperforming against the Buck, and perhaps somewhat perversely or counterintuitively as reports emerged about various vaccines for the virus that could be ready within months. This undermined the safest havens, with the Franc reversing sharply below 0.9700 and Yen back under 109.00 after contrasting Swiss trade data and running into resistance ahead of a key Fib at 108.66 respectively. However, the Aussie and Kiwi failed to derive much comfort off multi-week lows circa 0.6738 and 0.6522, as Aud/Usd eyes Q4 CPI hot on the heels of weak NAB business confidence and conditions, while Nzd/Usd awaits trade metrics for December after the Fed.

CAD/NOK/SEK

The Loonie and Norwegian Crown appear to have gleaned some support/traction from a rebound in oil to pare losses from sub-1.3200 vs the Buck and 10.1150+ against the Euro, but mainly a bit less investor angst over the Chinese health issue that lifted some of the market gloom broadly, while the Swedish Crown also rebounded from early lows vs the single currency after inconclusive macro releases and containing declines through a Fib in advance of the 200 DMA.

EM

The aforementioned better virus news (comparatively speaking) also helped the Yuan stop the rot (for now at least), as Usd/Cnh was capped ahead of 7.0000, while the Mexican Peso found some solace in wider trade surpluses. However, the Hungarian Forint revisited Monday’s record lows after a dovish NBH hold and the Rouble shrugged off softer than forecast Russian retail sales and real wages in favour of the recovery in crude prices.

content: Bonds were already unwinding safe haven premiums before a big headline US durables goods beat, but are still on the retreat even though back data was downgraded and sub-components missed consensus. In fact, Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries are only a few ticks off new session lows of 173.89, 134.68 and 130-20+ vs 174.48, 135.28 and 131-06 at best on a general rebound in risk appetite and bounce in EU equities/US stock futures ahead of the Wall Street open in wake of latest reports on China’s CV and decent results/guidance from Pfizer, overall. Conversely, the Greenback is still underpinned and edging a bit further above the 98.000 level in DXY terms to 98.104 at one stage, with Eur/Usd and Cable looking increasingly vulnerable on the 1.1000 and 1.3000 handles respectively.

subject: UK Government have given permission for Huawei to construct non-core sections of the UK telecom network, has been designated a high-risk vendor; have a market share cap of 35% and excluded from sensitive geographic locations
analysis_details:
• The decision by the UK to let Huawei take part in the UK’s 5G infrastructure comes in line with UK press reports. With the Chinese telecom giant now allowed to build parts of the 'non-critical' infrastructure for the network, focus shifts towards any potential strains on UK-US relations. 
  • The decision will likely be met with disappointment by the Trump administration with this sentiment likely to be echoed by US Secretary of State Pompeo, while will be visiting London tomorrow. UBS highlights that Republicans in Congress believe that the decision means that co-operation on security between the two nations needs to be re-calibrated in order to protect US interests. Those taking an even more hawkish view could be inclined to cast doubts over the viability of a US-UK FT. 
  • Note, PM Johnson will travel to Washington next week for the commencement of trade talks, however, UBS suggests that President Trump could be more inclined to exert pressure on contentious bilateral issues such as Huawei, Iran or digital taxation rather than discussion options for a trade deal.

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 28th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Upside in European bourses wanes as coronavirus remains a concern
  • World Health Organisation states that they have not seen any onward human-to-human spread of coronavirus by travelers returning from China; aside from one case
  • China National Health Commission confirmed 4515 cases of coronavirus and total deaths at 106 as of end-January 27th
  • OPEC are reportedly discussing extending oil output cuts until at least June, could deepen output cuts if prices & demand falls on spread of the coronavirus
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Durables, Case-Shiller, Consumer Confidence, Richmond Fed, UK Announcement on Huawei, ECB’s Lane, supply from US
  • Earnings: Apple, Pfizer, United Tech, Lockheed Martin, Starbucks, 3M Co, Stryker , Advanced Micro Devices, HCA Healthcare, T. Rowe Price, Equity Residential, eBay, Royal Caribbean Cruises, Paccar, Xilinx, McCormick & Company, Boston Properties, Maxim Integrated Products, Nucor, Principal Financial Group, Wynn Resorts, W. R. Berkley, Franklin Resource, PulteGroup

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

China National Health Commission confirmed 4515 cases of coronavirus and total deaths at 106 as of end-January 27th, while China postponed the spring semester for schools due to the coronavirus although did not provide the exact opening dates. (Newswires)

Hong Kong Government instructed all its employees to work from home until next week and will review the measure at that time, while it urged private companies to follow suit due to the coronavirus. (Newswires) Hong Kong government states that Hong Kong markets will trade as normal on January 29th. (Newswires)

World Health Organisation states that they have not seen any onward human-to-human spread of coronavirus by travelers returning from China, aside from one case in Vietnam; which is good news. (Newswires) Note, it is not entirely clear as to how timely this report is with reference to if it encapsulated the below virus reports out of Japan/Germany

A second case of the virus has been reported in Japan in an individual who has no history of travelling to Wuhan. Note, it does not explicitly state that he has not been to Wuhan or China, just no history of travelling to Wuhan. Separately a man in Germany has reportedly been infected with the coronavirus from a woman who travelled to Wuhan, this is being portrayed as person-to-person transmission, although it is unclear if this is explicitly the case. (Newswires)

Canadian government told its citizens to avoid all travel to the Hubei province. In other news, US FDA announced key actions to advance development of medical countermeasures against the coronavirus in which it is actively working to facilitate the development and availability of diagnostics that can detect the virus. (Newswires)

Twitter reports noted the first coronavirus case in Germany has been confirmed. (Twitter)

ASIA-PAC

Hefty losses were suffered across Asia-Pac bourses as virus-induced fears caught up to several indices on their return from the extended weekend and which followed Wall St’s worst performance in nearly 4 months. ASX 200 (-1.4%) traded subdued as the energy and mining related sectors led the declines due to concerns of the impact to demand and growth from the virus epidemic, although gold stocks bucked the trend after the recent safe-haven bid for the precious metal and defensives were also resilient in the downturn. Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) was pressured by the outbreak jitters as the number of confirmed cases in China rose to 4515 and total deaths at 106, considering that the Chinese account for around 30% of foreign tourists to Japan. KOSPI (-3.1%) and Singapore Straits (-2.5%) slumped in their first trading session after the Lunar New Year in reaction to the increased number of virus cases confirmed in China and their individual countries, while India’s NIFTY Index (Unch.) was indecisive with earnings the main driver for domestic stocks. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat amid slight fatigue from the recent extended rally and after mixed results at today’s 40yr JGB auction, although downside was also restricted due to the sell-off across regional stocks.

PBoC states that the Central Bank will offer abundant liquidity after the Lunar New Year Holiday through Open Market Operations. (Newswires)

US Former US National Security Adviser Bolton privately told AG Barr last year that he had concerns President Trump was effectively granting favours to the autocrats of Turkey and China, according to reports citing excerpts from Bolton's unpublished book. (NYT)

US Senator Toomey proposed a ‘one-for-one’ witness deal for the impeachment trial after Bolton’s revelation and Senator Romney is generally supportive of a witness deal but has not yet signed on to a plan, according to Washington Post's Costa. (Twitter)

UK/EU

EU is demanding that its judges have the authority to rule on any post-Brexit agreement with the UK; areas of focus will include trade, fishing and security. (Times)

As a reminder, UK PM Johnson is today expected to announce that Huawei will be allowed to build parts of the nation’s 5G network, despite warnings from the US administration; statement expected after 15:00GMT (Telegraph) Subsequently, EU will not ban Huawei from their telecommuncations network, but will be imposing strict 5G rules., according to AFP citing an Official. (AFP)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump's Middle East Plan will offer Palestine a path to statehood according to reports citing leaks of the plan. (Newswires/Washington Post)

US Secretary of State Pompeo tweeted that ruthless actions by Russia, Iranian regime, Hizballah and the Assad regime are directly preventing the establishment of a ceasefire in northern Syria, while he added we condemn the barbaric attacks and call for an immediate ceasefire. (Twitter)

EQUITIES

Overall a mixed session thus far in the European equity space [Eurostoxx 50 +0.1] following on from a predominantly downbeat APAC handover as coronavirus jitters hit multiple bourses on their return from holidays. For reference, Hong Kong confirmed that its stock markets will trade as normal on January 29th, whilst Shanghai and Shenzen return on February 3rd. Back to Europe, FTSE MIB (+0.5%) outperforms its peers amid further tailwinds from the weekend’s regional election which diminished the chance of a snap election in the country. Meanwhile, Netherland’s AEX (-0.2%) modestly lags following earnings from Philips (-2.7%) after reporting sub-par earnings, albeit the company noted that it is reviewing options for its domestic appliances’ business. Philips holds a 6.2% weighting in the Dutch bourse. Sectors are mixed with no clear reflection of the overall risk-tone, although the IT sector (-0.9%) underperforms on account of earnings from SAP (-2.7%), despite what seemed to be positive on the surface. The DAX-giant (accounts for 10.5% of the index) raised profit revenue guidance but narrowed its all-important 2020 cloud sales to the range of EUR 8.7-9.0bln from the prior EUR 8.6-9.1bln. In terms of stock specifics – Airbus (+1.2%) rose in excess of 2% at the open the Co. reached a deal to settle corruption probes. Meanwhile, Bayer (+0.6%) shares remain supported amid a positive broker move at MainFirst Bank. As a reminder, 14 DJIA companies will be reporting this week, with today’s slate including 3M (4.17% weighting), Pfizer (0.95% weighting) and United Technologies (3.59% weighting) before market open followed by Apple (7.3% weighting) after the bell.

FX

DXY/CHF/JPY/XAU - The traditional safe havens are back in vogue following a transitory and tame recovery in risk sentiment, as the Chinese coronavirus continues to unnerve markets amidst reports of the outbreak reaching further beyond the region. The Dollar is in demand almost across the board as a result, with the DXY pivoting 98.000 and briefly crossing Fib resistance just above the big figure at 98.011 before topping out at 98.035 in part due to fractional outperformance in the Franc and Yen that are holding above 0.9700 and 109.00 respectively. Conversely, Gold has handed back some of yesterday’s gains, but remains relatively well bid within a tight Usd1577-1583/oz range and technically bullish around 20 Bucks over last Friday’s circa Usd1566.62 low.

AUD/NZD/GBP - The major losers on a combination of contagion from China and cross flows for month end as the Aussie teeters around 0.6750 and not far from deeper troughs posted last October ahead of 0.6700, Kiwi hovers close to the base of 0.6550-22 parameters and Sterling skirts 1.3000. Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd are still inversely correlated to moves in Usd/Cnh-Cny on breaking virus updates in the absence of official daily PBoC settings during the Lunar New Year break, with the Yuan inching nearer the 7.0000 mark again having reached peaks beyond 6.8500 only 8 days ago on the crest of the Phase 1 trade deal signing. Meanwhile, Cable is trading cautiously into Thursday’s BoE/MPC rate announcement and Brexit the day after, as market contacts note RHS interest in Eur/Gbp for month end that has lifted cross through 0.8450.

EUR/CAD/SEK/NOK - The Euro has survived another test of bids/support into the 1.1000 level, partly on the purported orders for January 31 noted above, but perhaps also benefiting from the common currency’s semi-safe haven status, while the Loonie has extended losses alongside the Norwegian Krona amidst yet another decline in crude prices. Usd/Cad has absorbed more offers at 1.3200, though not all and supply is said to be stacked up to 1.3210, while Eur/Nok has been up to 10.1155 and higher than Eur/Sek in percentage terms after mixed Swedish data in the form of retail sales, trade and ppi saw the latter briefly breach a Fib (10.6121), but not really threaten the 200 DMA (circa 10.6400).

Notable FX Expiries, NY Cut:

-        USD/JPY: 108.75-80 (1.2BLN)

FIXED

It took another few attempts and appeared to be driven by a stop-chase in US Treasuries, but all core bonds did eventually breach Monday’s intraday peaks to set fresh nascent wtd peaks, at 131-06, 174.48 and 135.28 respectively. However, a lack of follow-through buying after the buy orders were filled and some better news on the China virus front via the WHO alongside more reports that OPEC+ could well extend its production caps have seen 10 year T-notes, Bunds and Gilts slip back, with the latter also absorbing DMO supply and the core Eurozone debt future conceding ground to renewed BTP outperformance. Just out, UK CBI trades (missed consensus and disappointing given a much more upbeat trends survey) then several US data points and more issuance via 2 year FRNs and 7 year paper (Usd 20 bn and Usd 32 bn).

COMMODITIES

Another subdued European session for WTI and Brent font-month futures, as the benchmarks pare overnight gains amid the overhang of the coronavirus outbreak. WTI Mar’20 futures have given up their 53/bbl+ status (vs. overnight high of 53.25/bbl) and drifts towards mild support at 52.70/bbl. Meanwhile, its Brent counterpart hovers around 58.75/bbl (vs. overnight high of 59.35/bbl) ahead of yesterday’s low of ~58.50/bbl. OPEC sources noted that Russia has been keen to exit from the agreed upon OPEC+ cuts, but they would be prepared to stay on-board in the event that prices drop below USD 60/bbl. Heading into tonight’s weekly API private crude inventory release, desks note that the complex will likely focus more on the virus developments. Nonetheless, the release is expected to show a build of 300k barrels in crude stocks, gasoline a build of 1.5mln and distillates a draw of 1mln – according to some data vendors. For reference, Barclays note that the further virus woes could see a USD 2/bbl impact on oil process on the potential economic fallout, meanwhile, UBS retains its positive outlook on oil prices in H2 2020, with Brent recovering to USD 64/bbl - recommends investors with high-risk tolerance to sell downside in Brent from USD 50/bbl. Elsewhere, spot gold trades relatively lacklustre around the 1580/oz mark ahead of mild support ~1577/oz - ABN AMRO warn investors of a possible price correction in the coming weeks, while remaining bullish on the lustrous metal in the longer-term. Copper prices have continued bleeding amid the global-growth implications of the virus outbreak – as prices remain sub 2.60/lb (vs. Jan high of 2.87/lb) and around levels seen last October.

OPEC are reportedly discussing extending oil output cuts until at least June, could deepen output cuts if prices & demand falls on spread of the coronavirus., OPEC sources; Moscow has been keen to exit from the cuts, they would be prepared to stay on-board in the event that prices drop below USD 60/bbl according to sources. (Newswires)

Barclays suggested that if the 2003 SARS outbreak is any indication, the market has likely overreacted to the coronavirus partly due to stretched positioning and the lacklustre global macroeconomic backdrop, while it expects transitory oil demand erosion of about 0.6-0.8mln BPD in Q1 or 0.2mln BPD for FY20 and sees USD 2/bbl downside to their FY forecast for WTI and Brent of USD 57/bbl and USD 62/bbl respectively in which it cited compounding effects of spillover

subject: Newsquawk EU Mid Session: Stocks cautious as virus spreads, focus turns to earnings - 28th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

Overall a mixed session thus far in the European equity space [Eurostoxx 50 +0.1] following on from a predominantly downbeat APAC handover as coronavirus jitters hit multiple bourses on their return from holidays. For reference, Hong Kong confirmed that its stock markets will trade as normal on January 29th, whilst Shanghai and Shenzen return on February 3rd. Back to Europe, FTSE MIB (+0.5%) outperforms its peers amid further tailwinds from the weekend’s regional election which diminished the chance of a snap election in the country. Meanwhile, Netherland’s AEX (-0.2%) modestly lags following earnings from Philips (-2.7%) after reporting sub-par earnings, albeit the company noted that it is reviewing options for its domestic appliances’ business. Philips holds a 6.2% weighting in the Dutch bourse. Sectors are mixed with no clear reflection of the overall risk-tone, although the IT sector (-0.9%) underperforms on account of earnings from SAP (-2.7%), despite what seemed to be positive on the surface. The DAX-giant (accounts for 10.5% of the index) raised profit revenue guidance but narrowed its all-important 2020 cloud sales to the range of EUR 8.7-9.0bln from the prior EUR 8.6-9.1bln. In terms of stock specifics – Airbus (+1.2%) rose in excess of 2% at the open the Co. reached a deal to settle corruption probes. Meanwhile, Bayer (+0.6%) shares remain supported amid a positive broker move at MainFirst Bank. As a reminder, 14 DJIA companies will be reporting this week, with today’s slate including 3M (4.17% weighting), Pfizer (0.95% weighting) and United Technologies (3.59% weighting) before market open followed by Apple (7.3% weighting) after the bell.

FX

DXY/CHF/JPY/XAU - The traditional safe havens are back in vogue following a transitory and tame recovery in risk sentiment, as the Chinese coronavirus continues to unnerve markets amidst reports of the outbreak reaching further beyond the region. The Dollar is in demand almost across the board as a result, with the DXY pivoting 98.000 and briefly crossing Fib resistance just above the big figure at 98.011 before topping out at 98.035 in part due to fractional outperformance in the Franc and Yen that are holding above 0.9700 and 109.00 respectively. Conversely, Gold has handed back some of yesterday’s gains, but remains relatively well bid within a tight Usd1577-1583/oz range and technically bullish around 20 Bucks over last Friday’s circa Usd1566.62 low.

AUD/NZD/GBP - The major losers on a combination of contagion from China and cross flows for month end as the Aussie teeters around 0.6750 and not far from deeper troughs posted last October ahead of 0.6700, Kiwi hovers close to the base of 0.6550-22 parameters and Sterling skirts 1.3000. Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd are still inversely correlated to moves in Usd/Cnh-Cny on breaking virus updates in the absence of official daily PBoC settings during the Lunar New Year break, with the Yuan inching nearer the 7.0000 mark again having reached peaks beyond 6.8500 only 8 days ago on the crest of the Phase 1 trade deal signing. Meanwhile, Cable is trading cautiously into Thursday’s BoE/MPC rate announcement and Brexit the day after, as market contacts note RHS interest in Eur/Gbp for month end that has lifted cross through 0.8450.

EUR/CAD/SEK/NOK - The Euro has survived another test of bids/support into the 1.1000 level, partly on the purported orders for January 31 noted above, but perhaps also benefiting from the common currency’s semi-safe haven status, while the Loonie has extended losses alongside the Norwegian Krona amidst yet another decline in crude prices. Usd/Cad has absorbed more offers at 1.3200, though not all and supply is said to be stacked up to 1.3210, while Eur/Nok has been up to 10.1155 and higher than Eur/Sek in percentage terms after mixed Swedish data in the form of retail sales, trade and ppi saw the latter briefly breach a Fib (10.6121), but not really threaten the 200 DMA (circa 10.6400).

FIXED INCOME

It took another few attempts and appeared to be driven by a stop-chase in US Treasuries, but all core bonds did eventually breach Monday’s intraday peaks to set fresh nascent wtd peaks, at 131-06, 174.48 and 135.28 respectively. However, a lack of follow-through buying after the buy orders were filled and some better news on the China virus front via the WHO alongside more reports that OPEC+ could well extend its production caps have seen 10 year T-notes, Bunds and Gilts slip back, with the latter also absorbing DMO supply and the core Eurozone debt future conceding ground to renewed BTP outperformance. Just out, UK CBI trades (missed consensus and disappointing given a much more upbeat trends survey) then several US data points and more issuance via 2 year FRNs and 7 year paper (Usd 20 bn and Usd 32 bn).

COMMODITIES                                                              

Another subdued European session for WTI and Brent font-month futures, as the benchmarks pare overnight gains amid the overhang of the coronavirus outbreak. WTI Mar’20 futures have given up their 53/bbl+ status (vs. overnight high of 53.25/bbl) and drifts towards mild support at 52.70/bbl. Meanwhile, its Brent counterpart hovers around 58.75/bbl (vs. overnight high of 59.35/bbl) ahead of yesterday’s low of ~58.50/bbl. OPEC sources noted that Russia has been keen to exit from the agreed upon OPEC+ cuts, but they would be prepared to stay on-board in the event that prices drop below USD 60/bbl. Heading into tonight’s weekly API private crude inventory release, desks note that the complex will likely focus more on the virus developments. Nonetheless, the release is expected to show a build of 300k barrels in crude stocks, gasoline a build of 1.5mln and distillates a draw of 1mln – according to some data vendors. For reference, Barclays note that the further virus woes could see a USD 2/bbl impact on oil process on the potential economic fallout, meanwhile, UBS retains its positive outlook on oil prices in H2 2020, with Brent recovering to USD 64/bbl - recommends investors with high-risk tolerance to sell downside in Brent from USD 50/bbl. Elsewhere, spot gold trades relatively lacklustre around the 1580/oz mark ahead of mild support ~1577/oz - ABN AMRO warn investors of a possible price correction in the coming weeks, while remaining bullish on the lustrous metal in the longer-term. Copper prices have continued bleeding amid the global-growth implications of the virus outbreak – as prices remain sub 2.60/lb (vs. Jan high of 2.87/lb) and around levels seen last October.

Coronavirus Update: A second case of the virus has been reported in Japan in an individual who has no history of travelling to Wuhan. Note, it does not explicitly state that he has not been to Wuhan or China, just no history of travelling to Wuhan
content: • The Kyodo article on this adds: The bus driver in his 60s drove two groups of Chinese tourists from Wuhan earlier this month, Japanese health minister Katsunobu Kato said.
analysis_details:
• For reference, the World Health's Organisation requirements to re-classify the Coronavirus are reported to include person-to-person transmission of the virus outside of those who have been to the Wuhan area
  • World Health Organisation have previously stated they were aware of only a single case of person-to-person transmission outside of China, with this having occurred in Vietnam
  • The World Health Organisation's current classification of the virus is that the risk is very high in China, and high at both a regional and global level. This classification means it is not seen as an international health emergency/emergency of international concern
  • A full analysis piece on the Coronavirus is available on the Newsquawk feed via this link

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling futures hovering below Monday’s lofty peaks
content: In keeping with the consolidative tone elsewhere, UK debt and STIR contracts have drifted back from yesterday’s best levels awaiting more updates from China and other countries afflicted by the outbreak, while acknowledging a mild bounce in EU stocks from their lows. However, the retracements are tentative and Gilts have peeked above Monday’s 135.17 pinnacle already after a bounce from 135.03 at one stage. Nevertheless, supply could be an issue given Gbp2.75 bn 2029 paper looming, while the CBI distributive trades survey will also be eyed following last week’s industrial trends findings that caused more than a stir.

subject: Bankia (BKIA IM) - Co's CFO expects a 2020 NII decline

content: Some signs of stability in risk assets after Monday’s mauling, but the 10 year German bond retains a firm underlying bid amidst the ongoing spread of China’s coronavirus and with less competition from Italian BTPs after their post-weekend regional election euphoria. Indeed, Bunds have bounced from worst levels just shy of the 174.00 handle after opening at 174.11 vs yesterday’s 174.23 close and an overnight high of 174.27 that matched Monday’s peak and now forms resistance ahead of the psychological 174.50 mark. Ahead, no further Eurozone data, but a busier US schedule and a speech from ECB’s Lane.

28th January 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Hefty losses were suffered across Asia-Pac bourses as virus-induced fears caught up to several indices on their return from the extended weekend and which followed Wall St’s worst performance in nearly 4 months. ASX 200 (-1.4%) traded subdued as the energy and mining related sectors led the declines due to concerns of the impact to demand and growth from the virus epidemic, although gold stocks bucked the trend after the recent safe-haven bid for the precious metal and defensives were also resilient in the downturn. Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) was pressured by the outbreak jitters as the number of confirmed cases in China rose to 4515 and total deaths at 106, considering that the Chinese account for around 30% of foreign tourists to Japan. KOSPI (-3.1%) and Singapore Straits (-2.5%) slumped in their first trading session after the Lunar New Year in reaction to the increased number of virus cases confirmed in China and their individual countries, while India’s NIFTY Index (Unch.) was indecisive with earnings the main driver for domestic stocks.

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 28th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Hefty losses were suffered across Asia-Pac bourses as virus-induced fears caught up to several indices on their return from the extended weekend
  • China National Health Commission confirmed 4515 cases of coronavirus and total deaths at 106 as of end-January 27th
  • Hong Kong Government instructed all its employees to work from home until next week and will review the measure at the time
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Durables, Case-Shiller, Consumer Confidence, Richmond Fed, UK Announcement on Huawei, ECB’s Lane, supply from Italy, UK and US
  • Earnings: Apple, Pfizer, United Tech, Lockheed Martin, Starbucks, 3M Co, Stryker , Advanced Micro Devices, HCA Healthcare, T. Rowe Price, Equity Residential, eBay, Royal Caribbean Cruises, Paccar, Xilinx, McCormick & Company, Boston Properties, Maxim Integrated Products, Nucor, Principal Financial Group, Wynn Resorts, W. R. Berkley, Franklin Resource, PulteGroup

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

China National Health Commission confirmed 4515 cases of coronavirus and total deaths at 106 as of end-January 27th, while China postponed the spring semester for schools due to the coronavirus although did not provide the exact opening dates. (Newswires)

Hong Kong Government instructed all its employees to work from home until next week and will review the measure at that time, while it urged private companies to follow suit due to the coronavirus. (Newswires) Hong Kong government states that Hong Kong markets will trade as normal on January 29th. (Newswires)

US raised China Travel Advisory to Level 3 which urges Americans to reconsider travel and the Canadian government told its citizens to avoid all travel to the Hubei province. In other news, US FDA announced key actions to advance development of medical countermeasures against the coronavirus in which it is actively working to facilitate the development and availability of diagnostics that can detect the virus. (Newswires)

Twitter reports noted the first coronavirus case in Germany has been confirmed. (Twitter)

ASIA-PAC

Hefty losses were suffered across Asia-Pac bourses as virus-induced fears caught up to several indices on their return from the extended weekend and which followed Wall St’s worst performance in nearly 4 months. ASX 200 (-1.4%) traded subdued as the energy and mining related sectors led the declines due to concerns of the impact to demand and growth from the virus epidemic, although gold stocks bucked the trend after the recent safe-haven bid for the precious metal and defensives were also resilient in the downturn. Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) was pressured by the outbreak jitters as the number of confirmed cases in China rose to 4515 and total deaths at 106, considering that the Chinese account for around 30% of foreign tourists to Japan. KOSPI (-3.1%) and Singapore Straits (-2.5%) slumped in their first trading session after the Lunar New Year in reaction to the increased number of virus cases confirmed in China and their individual countries, while India’s NIFTY Index (Unch.) was indecisive with earnings the main driver for domestic stocks. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat amid slight fatigue from the recent extended rally and after mixed results at today’s 40yr JGB auction, although downside was also restricted due to the sell-off across regional stocks.

UK/EU

ECB’s Mersch says the risks of an asset price correction are rising, current valuations are at high levels; it is preferable to incorporate financial stability concerns into ECB policy deliberations. (Newswires)

EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier said there is no possibility for frictionless trade between the EU and the UK. (Newswires)

EU is demanding that its judges have the authority to rule on any post-Brexit agreement with the UK; areas of focus will include trade, fishing and security. (Times)

 

As a reminder, UK PM Johnson is today expected to announce that Huawei will be allowed to build parts of the nation’s 5G network, despite warnings from the US administration. (Telegraph)

FX

DXY held on to the prior day’s gains near the 98.00 level after having recently surmounted its 200DMA, although overnight price momentum for the greenback has petered out heading closer to Wednesday’s FOMC and with reports suggesting Senate Republicans are warming to the idea of calling former National Security Adviser Bolton to testify at the impeachment trial. EUR/USD was subdued within the tight range seen so far this week, not helped by the softer than expected German IFO data, and GBP/USD traded choppy around 1.3050 as it bided time prior to the key events later this week including the BoE meeting and Brexit date. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses languished on the widespread risk averse tone although the former made several attempts to regain a footing on the 109.00 handle, while antipodeans were lacklustre owing to their high-beta statuses and the China-related concerns.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were uneventful overnight in which price action consolidated following yesterday’s risk-driven moves which kept oil  subdued, although Brent crude and WTI crude futures are off their lows and just about reclaimed the USD 59.00/bbl and USD 53.00/bbl levels respectively. There were also comments overnight from Barclays which expects oil demand erosion of 600k-800k bpd for Q1 but also suggested the possibility markets overreacted to the coronavirus due to stretched positioning and lacklustre macroeconomic environment. Elsewhere, gold proceeded sideways and held on to the spoils of the recent safe-haven flows, while copper languished on the broad regional equity sell-off although has found a base around the 2.60/lb level.

 

Venezuela is mulling privatizing its oil industry amid its financial struggles, with names touted including Repsol, Eni and Rosneft, according to sources. (Newswires)

 

Barclays suggested that if the 2003 SARS outbreak is any indication, the market has likely overreacted to the coronavirus partly due to stretched positioning and the lacklustre global macroeconomic backdrop, while it expects transitory oil demand erosion of about 0.6-0.8mln BPD in Q1 or 0.2mln BPD for FY20 and sees USD 2/bbl downside to their FY forecast for WTI and Brent of USD 57/bbl and USD 62/bbl respectively in which it cited compounding effects of spillover to growth from China and region. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump's Middle East Plan will offer Palestine a path to statehood according to reports citing leaks of the plan, while there were separate comments from Israeli Centrist Leader Gantz who will look to implement US President Trump's 'landmark' peace plan immediately after the Israeli election. (Newswires/Washington Post)

 

An Iranian Minister stated they are preparing a new satellite launch site, although the US suggested it is a cover for the development of ballistic missiles. (Newswires)

 

US Secretary of State Pompeo tweeted that ruthless actions by Russia, Iranian regime, Hizballah and the Assad regime are directly preventing the establishment of a ceasefire in northern Syria, while he added we condemn the barbaric attacks and call for an immediate ceasefire. (Twitter)

 

US 

Yields were lower by around 4-8bps, bull flattening; major curve spreads had narrowed between 1-3bps, with much attention on the 2s5s spread, which went negative again after a lacklustre 2-year auction. Yesterday's price action was a result of the Coronavirus updates, which are beginning to weigh on perceptions of global growth. The US sold 2-year and 5-year notes, the latter tailing by 0.1bps at the lowest yield since August 2017, while the 5-year sale was weak, tailing by 1.1bps. US T-Note futures settled 19+ ticks higher at 130-28+.

Former US National Security Adviser Bolton privately told AG Barr last year that he had concerns President Trump was effectively granting favours to the autocrats of Turkey and China, according to reports citing excerpts from Bolton's unpublished book. (NYT)

US Senator Toomey proposed a ‘one-for-one’ witness deal for the impeachment trial after Bolton’s revelation and Senator Romney is generally supportive of a witness deal but has not yet signed on to a plan, according to Washington Post's Costa. (Twitter)

subject: Hong Kong government states that Hong Kong markets will trade as normal on January 29th
analysis_details:
• This comes after China has announced that the Lunar New Year holiday will be extended by an additional 3-days. At present, it is unclear if financial markets in the region will re-open on Friday once the original holiday period has concluded or remain closed until Monday in-line with the extension to the holiday period itself.
  • While a significant move by the Chinese Government, designed to stem the spread of the virus during the heightened period of travel, it is a step which has taken place before. In 2003, due to the SARS outbreak, the May market holiday was extended by an additional 4-days.

content:

ASX 200 (-1.3%) is subdued with the energy and mining related sectors leading the declines in Australia amid concerns of the impact to demand and growth from the virus epidemic, although gold stocks buck the trend due to the recent safe-haven bid and with defensives also showing some resilience amid the downturn. Nikkei 225 (-1.0%) is also weighed by the outbreak concerns in which the number of confirmed cases in China increased to 4515 and total deaths at 106, considering that the Chinese account for around 30% of foreign tourists to Japan, while KOSPI (-3.3%) and Singapore Straits (-2.6%) have slumped in their first trading session following the Lunar New Year and react to the increased number of virus cases confirmed in China and their individual countries.

In FX markets, the DXY holds on to the prior day’s gains near the 98.00 level after having recently surmounted its 200DMA, although overnight price momentum for the greenback has since petered out heading closer to Wednesday’s FOMC and with reports suggesting some Senate Republicans are warming to the idea of calling former National Security Adviser Bolton to testify in the impeachment trial. EUR/USD is subdued within the tight range seen so far this week, not helped by the softer than expected German IFO data, and GBP/USD is choppy around 1.3050 as it bides time prior the key events later this week including the BoE meeting and Brexit date. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses languish on the widespread risk averse tone although the former is attempting to reclaim a footing on the 109.00 handle, while antipodeans are lacklustre owing to their high-beta statuses and China-related concerns.

Finally, 10yr JGBs remain afloat due to the sell-off across regional stocks, although the gains are limited for JGBs following its recent extended rally and as participants await the 40yr auction.
